title: Prepare for a multipolar currency world

concepts.name: Multipolar Currency Regime
concepts.description: A global financial system where multiple currencies share reserve status, replacing a single dominant hegemony.
concepts.real_world_context: Emerges as geopolitical blocs solidify; regime-dependent on the decline of the Bretton Woods II framework.

concepts.name: Dollar Hegemony
concepts.description: The dominance of the US dollar in global debt markets and trade, creating exposure to US policy for other nations.
concepts.real_world_context: Historically stable but facing structural fragility due to weaponization of sanctions.

concepts.name: Renminbi Internationalization
concepts.description: China's strategic push to increase the use of RMB in cross-border settlements and reserves.
concepts.real_world_context: Accelerated by Russia-China trade; limited by capital controls but expanding via 'shadow' channels.

concepts.name: Weaponized Sanctions
concepts.description: The use of financial access as a geopolitical tool (e.g., freezing reserves).
concepts.real_world_context: Creates incentives for target nations to seek alternative payment rails.

relationships.description: Sanctions on Russia accelerate the adoption of RMB for trade to bypass US control.
The rise of alternative currency blocs structurally reduces the dominance and 'exorbitant privilege' of the dollar.
Direct strategic conflict between the incumbent reserve currency and the challenger.

title: Chinaâ€™s tech giants take AI model training offshore to tap Nvidia chips

concepts.name: US Export Controls
concepts.description: Restrictions on the sale of high-performance semiconductors to China.
concepts.real_world_context: Intended to slow China's AI progress; creates market distortions and regulatory arbitrage.

concepts.name: Offshore Data Centers
concepts.description: Computing facilities located in neutral jurisdictions (e.g., Singapore) used to access restricted hardware.
concepts.real_world_context: A loophole or adaptation mechanism in response to geopolitical trade barriers.

concepts.name: Regulatory Arbitrage
concepts.description: Exploiting jurisdictional differences to bypass regulations.
concepts.real_world_context: Companies move physical training loads to locations where US bans are less strictly enforced or inapplicable.

relationships.description: The ban on chips within China directly causes the demand for offshore compute capacity.
The ability to train offshore dampens the effectiveness of the export controls.
